messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-30T19:40:40Z
## Message ID: 20210430-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-04-30T15:30Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting on 2021-04-23. Peak solar wind speed at L1 was 538 km/s at 2021-04-27T19:42Z, the current solar wind speed is 322 km/s. The C-type CME observed on 2021-04-22T05:23Z with an arrival detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR on 2021-04-24T22:24Z could also be associated with this elevation in energetic electron flux levels.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-04-28T18:20:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 21, 2021 - April 27, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-29T04:20:59Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-04-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-04-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210429-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with two C-type CMEs (see details below).  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and ensemble heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the CME starting at 2021-04-22T05:23Z may impact missions near Earth with an average arrival around 2021-04-24T19:25Z and an average arrival at STEREO-A around 2021-04-25T00:59Z (See notifications 20210422-AL-001 and 20210423-AL-001). The second C-type CME that started on 2021-04-25T13:25Z was estimated to impact STEREO-A around 2021-04-28T08:43Z (plus/minus 7 hours).  A CME arrival was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-04-24T22:24Z associated with the CME that started on 2021-04-22T05:23Z (see notification 20210425-AL-001).  The STEREO A IMPACT instrument also detected a CME arrival on 2021-04-28T02:58Z associated with the CME that started on 2021-04-25T13:25Z. 

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-04-23T21:00Z-24:00Z, 2021-04-25T00:00Z-03:00Z, and 2021-04-26T03:00Z-06:00Z. These elevated values of Kp were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-04-23, as well as the arrival at 2021-04-24T22:24Z of the CME that started on 2021-04-22T05:23Z. Solar wind speeds reached values around 550 km/s during the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu throughout the first half of the reporting period until 2021-04-25. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with the combination of the continued influence of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-04-17 and the second coronal hole high speed stream detected around 2021-04-23 (see notifications 20210421-AL-002 and 20210423-AL-002).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO-A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to elevated energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-04-22T05:23Z     ~803            C               -13/-8                30                          SOHO, STEREO-A                    

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-04-25T13:25Z     ~652            C              -41/-15                23                          SOHO                    
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-04-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-05-04T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period.  There are several active regions present on the solar surface as seen in the available imagery with the potential to produce flares and coronal mass ejections. Active Region 12816 produced two C-class flares during the reporting period, but is due to rotate off of the Earth-facing disk near the beginning of the outlook period.  Active Region 12820 produced several B-class flares during the reporting period and may produce several B- and C-class flares early in the outlook period.  There are a couple of unnumbered active regions about to rotate onto the STEREO-A-facing disk that may produce some minor flaring activity.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels for the outlook period.  Potential causes of enhanced geomagnetic activity include the possible arrival of a high speed stream from a coronal hole near center disk on 2021-04-28, which may become geoeffective around 2021-05-02.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-04-28T18:20Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting on 2021-04-23. Peak solar wind speed at L1 was 538 km/s at 2021-04-27T19:42Z, the current solar wind speed is 351 km/s. The C-type CME observed on 2021-04-22T05:23Z with an arrival detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR on 2021-04-24T22:24Z could also be associated with this elevation in energetic electron flux levels.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-04-28T18:20:00-RBE-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-25T12:27:48Z
## Message ID: 20210425-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2021-04-24T22:24Z. 

The shock is caused by the CME with ID 2021-04-22T05:23:00-CME-001 (see notification(s) 20210422-AL-001, 20210423-AL-001).

Activity ID: 2021-04-24T22:24:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-23T16:55:29Z
## Message ID: 20210423-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-04-23T05:40Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-04-17 are caused by high speed stream starting on 2021-04-16. A subsequent high speed stream observed on 2021-04-17 further enhanced the electron fluxes starting at 2021-04-19T09:35Z (See notifications 20210417-AL-001, 20210417-AL-002, 20210419-AL-001, 20210419-AL-002, and 20210421-AL-002). This second high speed stream exhibited a maximum solar wind speed of 689 km/s. The current solar wind speed at L1 is approximately 377 km/s.


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-04-17T16:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-23T13:11:17Z
## Message ID: 20210423-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2021-04-22T05:23:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20210422-AL-001). Based on preliminary analysis of the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and ensemble heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2021-04-24T12:14Z and 2021-04-25T10:31Z (average arrival 2021-04-25T00:59Z) for 60% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-04-24T08:18Z and 2021-04-25T10:19Z (average arrival 2021-04-24T19:25Z) for 93% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 74% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-22_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004/20210422_052300_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-22_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004/20210422_052300_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-22_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004/20210422_052300_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-22_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004/20210422_052300_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-22_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004/20210422_052300_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-22_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004/20210422_052300_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-22_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004/Detailed_results_20210422_052300_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA004.txt
###

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-22T16:54:34Z
## Message ID: 20210422-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-04-22T05:23Z.

Estimated speed: ~803 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 30 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -8/-13 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-04-22T05:23:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis of the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2021-04-25T22:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-04-24T17:24Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-04-22T05:23:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210422_093700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-04-22T05:23:00-CME-001) is associated with C3.8 flare with ID 2021-04-22T04:10:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-04-22T04:35Z.  This CME and the associated flare are from Active Region 12816.


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 14, 2021 - April 20, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-21T20:55:02Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-04-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-04-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210421-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with one M-class flare and two C-type CMEs (see details below).  Based on preliminary analysis of the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at the NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the CME starting at 2021-04-17T16:53Z may impact Mars around 2021-04-22T00:01Z, Solar Orbiter around 2021-04-19T16:16Z, and impact as a glancing blow at STEREO A around 2021-04-20T12:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours) (See notification 20210417-AL-003). The second C-type CME that started on 2021-04-20T00:12Z was associated with an M1.1 flare from Active Region 12816 located at S24E23 as viewed from the Earth-facing disk that started at 2021-04-19T23:19Z and peaked at 2021-04-19T23:42Z. This CME was estimated to impact STEREO A around 2021-04-22T20:31Z and as a glancing blow at missions near Earth around 2021-04-22T22:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours) (See notifications 20210420-AL-001 and 20210421-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-04-15T06:00Z-09:00Z, 2021-04-16T18:00Z-21:00Z, and 2021-04-17T00:00Z-09:00Z. These elevated values of Kp were associated with the arrival of two back-to-back coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-04-16 and 2021-04-17, respectively. Solar wind speeds from these high speed streams reached values around 686km/s and decreased to around 558km/s by the end of the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu throughout most of the reporting period starting on 2021-04-17 (see notifications 20210417-AL-001, 20210417-AL-002, 20210419-AL-001, and 20210419-AL-002). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with the combination of the two coronal hole high speed streams mentioned above detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-04-16 and 2021-04-17, respectively.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to elevated energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
2021-04-19  23:19:00  23:59:00  23:42:00   M1.1   S24E23 ( 12816 ) 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-04-20T00:12Z     ~583            C               -37/-7                28                          SOHO, STEREO A                    

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-04-17T16:36Z     ~710            C              -110/-4                41                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-04-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-04-27T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period.  There are several active regions present at the solar surface as seen on the available imagery with the potential to produce flares and coronal mass ejections. Active Region 12817 produced several B-class flares and a C-class flare near the end of the reporting period and may continue to produce B-class and possibly C-class flares early on in the outlook period as it rotates off of the Earth-facing disk.  Active Region 12816 produced an M-class flare on 2021-04-19 and may produce several B and C-class flares throughout the reporting period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels for the reporting period.  Potential causes of enhanced geomagnetic activity include the possible arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream observed to the NW of active region 12816 centered around S15W30 on 2021-04-21 as seen from the Earth facing disk that may become geoeffective around late 2021-04-23.  A southern extension of the northern pole coronal hole may also become geoeffective by the end of the outlook period.  The geomagnetic activity could also be slightly enhanced by the glancing blow impact from the 2021-04-20T00:12Z C-type CME mentioned above.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

A subsequent high speed stream observed on 2021-04-17 further enhanced the electron fluxes starting at 2021-04-19T09:35Z (See notifications 20210417-AL-001, 20210417-AL-002, 20210419-AL-001, and 20210419-AL-002). This second high speed stream exhibited a maximum solar wind speed of 689 km/s. The current solar wind speed at L1 is approximately 505 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-04-17T16:35:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2021-04-20T00:12:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20210420-AL-001). Based on analysis of the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2021-04-22T16:29Z and 2021-04-23T02:47Z (average arrival 2021-04-22T21:41Z) for 93% of simulations.

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-20_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA003/Detailed_results_20210420_001200_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA003.txt

Note: The ensemble simulation did not predict at direct impact at missions near Earth, but a glancing blow is possible around 2021-04-22T18:00Z. Results below:

Earth (summary, more details follow below):
Number_of_hits_Earth= 0
Number_of_miss_Earth=48
Percentage_hits_Earth= 0%
No CME simulation in this ensemble hit Earth or the impact is weak

Earth results for median input parameters:
Arrival time     maxKp(90,135,180) Rmin(Re) Duration (hrs)
None: CME did not hit Earth or impact is weak

https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-04-20_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA003/20210420_001200_ncmes1_sims48_LAHAINA003_anim_tim-vel.gif

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-20T17:18:35Z
## Message ID: 20210420-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-04-20T00:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~583 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 28 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -37/-7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-04-20T00:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center by the analysis of the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2021-04-22T20:31Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-04-22T22:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2021-04-20T00:12:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Kp_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210420_063800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif



## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-04-20T00:12:00-CME-001) is associated with an M1.1 flare with ID 2021-04-19T23:19:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2021-04-19T23:42Z. The source of the flare was AR2816 (S24E23).


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement (Correction)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-19T19:30:01Z
## Message ID: 20210419-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu since at 2021-04-19T09:35Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-04-19 are caused by high speed stream starting around 2021-04-16 (See notifications 20210417-AL-001 and 20210417-AL-002). A subsequent high speed stream observed at 2021-04-17 has further enhanced the electron fluxes starting at 2021-04-19T09:35Z. This second high speed stream exhibited a maximum solar wind speed of 689 km/s. The current solar wind speed at L1 is approximately 640 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-04-17T16:35:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2021-04-17T16:53Z.

Estimated speed: ~828 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 42 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -107/-8 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-04-17T16:53:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Mars, Solar Orbiter, and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Mars at 2021-04-22T00:01Z, Solar Orbiter at 2021-04-19T16:16Z, and STEREO A at 2021-04-20T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 07, 2021 - April 13, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-14T20:51:16Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-04-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-04-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210414-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity reached minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-04-07T15:00Z-18:00Z.  This enhanced geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-04-07, with solar wind speeds reaching values around 520 km/s on 2021-04-07.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was below the threshold level of 1000 pfu throughout the entire reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Two high speed streams were observed during the reporting period.  One high speed stream was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-04-07.  One high speed stream was detected by STEREO A on 2021-04-12.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-04-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-04-20T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period.  An S-type CME observed on 2021-04-10T06:53Z might give Earth a glancing blow on 2021-04-15T18:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours).  Another S-type CME observed on 2021-04-12T10:53Z is expected to arrive at Solar Orbiter on 2021-04-15T06:36Z (plus/minus 7 hours) and at Mars on 2021-04-18T00:30Z (plus/minus 7 hours).  A third S-type CME observed on 2021-04-13T11:53Z is expected to arrive at OSIRIS-REx on 2021-04-17T05:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours).

A small coronal hole observed to the NW of Active Region 2814 crossed the central meridian of the Earth-facing disk near the end of the reporting period and may become geoeffective near the middle of the outlook period.  A northern extension of the Southern Pole coronal hole to the East of Active Region 2814, near longitude E10 at the end of the reporting period, could impact STEREO A early in the outlook period and may become geoeffective near the end of the outlook period.

Active Region 2814 produced several B-class flares near the end of the reporting period and may continue to produce B-class flares during the outlook period.  An unnumbered Active Region visible near S20E40 in the STEREO A field of view at the end of the reporting period may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk early in the outlook period.  This AR is associated with multiple filament eruptions late in the reporting period and may be a source of increased Earth-facing activity early in the outlook period.  An unnumbered Active Region visible behind the eastern limb in the STEREO A field of view at the end of the reporting period may rotate onto the STEREO A-facing disk early in the outlook period and onto the Earth-facing disk late in the outlook period.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 31, 2021 - April 06, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-04-07T20:22:03Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-31T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-04-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210407-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 
  
Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period (see notifications 20210402-AL-001 and 20210402-AL-002). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with sporadic high speed stream influences detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 starting around 2021-03-30. In response to these intermittent high speed streams, the solar wind speed observed at L1 reached a maximum speed of 430 km/s on 2021-04-01. The solar wind speed observed at L1 gradually declined thereafter, remaining below 350 km/s during the last few days of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:

Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:

Flares (M-class and above)
Date        Start    Stop     Peak     Class  Location        
None Observed

None Observed

Starting time       Speed (km/s)  Type  Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)  Half-Angle width (degrees) Detecting spacecraft (real-time) 
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-04:07T00:00Z
## Outlook Coverage End Date: 2021-04-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active Region 12813 is expected to rotate off of the Earth-facing disk during the early portion of the outlook period.  There are still some minor unnumbered regions visible in the available EUV imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period due to the possible arrival of coronal holes high speed streams. These arrivals may be associated with a southern-latitude coronal hole structure that passed through the central meridian of the Earth-facing disk on 2021-04-03 and a cluster of diffuse coronal hole structures currently centered around the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO. Currently, the geomagnetic conditions are at minor levels with Kp=5 for the synoptic period of 2021-04-07T15:00Z-18:00Z, and the solar wind speed has reached a value of ~520 km/s.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 24, 2021 - March 30, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-31T20:44:16Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-03-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210331-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity reached minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2021-03-25T00:00Z-03:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity is associated with a S-type (<500 km/s) CME arrival. The CME was first visible in the coronagraph imagery on 2021-03-20T00:48Z and was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-03-24T19:18Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period (see notification 20210325-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the arrival of the S-type CME mentioned above. A weaker transient signature was also detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-03-24T04:57Z that may have contributed to the increase in the energetic electron flux.  The electron fluxes went back to nominal levels around 2021-03-27.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-04-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active regions 12811 and 12812 have decayed and are expected to rotate off of the Earth-facing disk during the early portion of the outlook period. Active regions 12811 and 12812 produced multiple A and B-class flares which may continue throughout the early portion of the next reporting period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the next outlook period due to the possible arrival of high speed streams from a cluster of coronal holes centered around the Earth-facing disk's meridian on 2021-03-30. There is also a small coronal hole structure that may cause a high speed stream at STEREO-A during the early portion of the next reporting period.
